collect organisms on or 
near the seafloor.  Bottom 
of net heavily weighted 
and dragged across 
seafloor.

Used in conjunction with 
FADS or with Dolphin-
associated Tuna schools

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.Fishing method used 
to catch pelagic 
predators, such as 
Tuna and Swordfish


2.Uses more than 
100km of fishing line 
and thousands 
baited hooks
 
Pelagic Long-Line Fishing:

Section II
Overfishing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The overfishing problem we see today is 
primarily the result of a dramatic shift to 
industrialized fishing operations that are run 
by large corporate holding companies that 
have little concern for conservation...
Overfishing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Shifting Trend To
 Industrialized Fishing... 
Fisheries Research 107 (2011) 131–136
Fishing Effort by Gross Registered Tonnage Class (GRT)...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Redrawn by Oceana
Each graph depicts the number of 
top predator fish (e.g., tuna & 
swordfish) caught per 100 hooks 
set by the global fishing fleet


This is a good proxy indicator for 
fish abundance
Myers and Worm (2003) 
 
NATURE: 423: 280-283 
Fish Caught per 100 Hooks Set
90% World-Wide Decline 
in Top Predator Fish

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Overall wild-captured biomass 
has leveled off since the 1990s 
at about 90 million tons 


One of the most striking trends 
of the past three decades has 
been the rise of aquaculture, 
which now provides about 
49%
 
of global fish production
 
http://www.fao.org/state-of-fisheries-aquaculture
World Fishery: 
 
Capture and Aquaculture

© 2023 Bruce Monger
93%
 
of the major world 
fisheries are currently 
either 
maximally 
exploited
 or 
overfished


Overfished fisheries
 grew 
from 10% in 1975 to about
 
43%
 
in 2019
Global Fishery 
Exploitation
http://www.fao.org/state-of-fisheries-aquaculture

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Globally, fisheries subsidies amount to about 
$35bn per year
. Without them, many high seas fisheries would 
probably not be economically viable. 


•
Subsidies are directly driving overfishing and associated environmental degradation
. 
2.
Economists tend to divide subsidies into ‘harmful’ and ‘beneficial’:


•
the most important ones in the ‘harmful’ category include: 
cheap fuel, funds for vessel construction, and 
support for the price of fish at market
. 


•
Without the fuel subsidy, trawling the bottom of the ocean, which is extremely 
damaging, would almost certainly stop. 
3.
Many governments support subsidy reform as a way of combatting overfishing and preserving deep-sea 
biodiversity.  Subsidies could be redirected to support conservation, or provide employment in coastal areas.


4.
Despite repeated commitments at the international level and initiatives within organizations such as the World Trade 
Organization, 
harmful subsidies remain — partly due to lobbying by vested interest groups.
http://www.globaloceancommission.org/policies/eliminating-harmful-fisheries-subsidies/
Globally Fisheries Subsidies

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Some poor countries rely almost entirely on fish to meet 
basic food needs...


2.
As rich/industrialized/mechanized countries remove vast 
amounts of fish from the ocean, the poor countries are being 
seriously hurt with few alternatives for relief... 
Social Injustice of Industrialized Overfishing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section III
The Unavoidable Problem of Bycatch: 
Bottom Trawling

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Bottom Trawling

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
As much as 
70%
 of sea life scraped up by the 
trawlers is undesirable and discarded back into 
the ocean - most often as dead animals
 
2.
Each year Trawling affects an area 
150X
 
greater than the global area of forest that is 
cleared
The Magnitude of the Problem

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Bottom Trawling 
BEFORE

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Bottom Trawling 
After

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Imagine if a deer hunter killed 
nearly every bird, mammal, 
reptile and insect in his/her 
path.


And simply left them lying dead 
and dying on the ground as 
they walked away with their 
single deer in hand.
Like Hunting Deer with 
Hand Grenades...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.treehugger.com/files/2008/02/trails_of_destr.php
Bottom Trawling is Taking 
Place Around the World 
on a Massive Scale...
Sediment Plumes From Trawlers 
Observed in Satellite Images

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.treehugger.com/files/2007/05/picture_worth_1_1.php
Sediment Plumes From Trawlers 
Observed in Satellite Images

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section IV
The Unavoidable Problem of Bycatch: 
Fish Aggregating Devices

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.pewenvironment.org/news-room/data-visualizations/proliferating-use-of-fish-aggregating-devices-85899482838
Fish Aggregating 
Devices (FADs)
1.
50%
 of the world’s Tuna is 
caught using FADs


2.
100,000
 FADS are deployed 
each year

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
FADs don't just attract target species 
(usually skipjack tuna). They also attract 
other non-target animals like juvenile 
yellowfin and bigeye tuna and sharks


2.
FADs increase bycatch by between 500 
and 1000 percent when compared to 
nets set on free-swimming schools. 
http://www.alternet.org/story/152025/4_dirty_secrets_hiding_in_your_tuna_can
Fish Aggregating Devices (FADs)
3.
15 to 20 percent of the total catch of a FAD-associated skipjack seine is actually juvenile 
yellowfin and bigeye which are threatened species

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Fish Aggregating Devices (FADs): A Big Marine Debris Problem
Tens of Thousands
 of FADs are abandoned every year


The nylon plastic netting and other synthetic materials wash up on 
beaches and snag on coral reefs and generally add to the marine 
debris problem across the oceans.
http://www.alternet.org/story/152025/4_dirty_secrets_hiding_in_your_tuna_can
https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-01222-z?utm_term=Autofeed&utm_campaign=nature&utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1651836363

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section V
The Unavoidable Problem of Bycatch: 
Longline Fishing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
In 1996, just three albatross species were threatened, but today all 21 species are at risk of 
extinction. A number of petrel species also face extinction. 
All of these seabirds are at risk as a 
result of longline fishing
.


2.
Sharks have also been severely impacted by longline fishing.  
Sharks have slow growth and 
reproductive rates that makes them particularly vulnerable to overfishing.
Longline fishing consists of a line of baited hooks 
often stretching more100 kilometers in length.  
Each longline can have 
several thousand baited 
hooks 
in a single set.  


The fishing method is intended to catch things 
like swordfish and tuna, but it also 
unintentionally catches seabirds, turtles and 
sharks
Longline ByCatch

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Seabirds 
Surrounding A 
Longline Fishing 
Boat

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Longline Fishing’s 
Unintended 
(Bycatch) Victims

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Gear Modification
Modifying fishing gear so 
that it reduces by catch


If done right, it is a win-win 
proposition for everyone


Bycatch of endangered 
species is reduced


Fishermen are not asked 
to reduce fishing effort of 
intended species

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section VI
Shark Finning 
Dynamite/Bomb Fishing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Shark Finning

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Shark Fin Soup

© 2023 Bruce Monger
A Billion-Dollar 
“Business”

© 2023 Bruce Monger
A Billion-Dollar 
“Business”

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Movie Trailer for Sharkwater

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MACg1lSfmnM
Optional Viewing...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Bycatch
 can be a highly subjective definition. For example, Spanish and 
Portuguese longliners specifically target sharks through the use of special bait, 
steel lines and special lights next to the hooks...


The distinction is very important, as commercially targeted shark fisheries must 
be managed with quotas and other instruments according to the Common 
Fisheries Policy, as is done for swordfish and tuna. 


But many shark catches are not managed at all because they are mostly still 
regarded as 
bycatch 
and so catch limits are almost non-existent.
http://www.oceana.org/europe/what-we-do/shark-conservation/research-photos/shark-fisheries/
A Note About the Current Lack of Shark Regulation...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/jan/27/sharks-rays-global-population-crashed-study?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other
70% World-Wide Loss of 
Sharks and Rays

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Dynamite/Bomb Fishing in Coral Reefs
1.
A single blast can destroy thousands of 
years of coral growth. Blast fishing stuns, 
injures and kills fish due to the immense 
pressure caused by the detonation.


2.
While some fish simply float to the surface 
where ready fishermen scoop them out of 
the water, a large percentage of unwanted 
species sink or float away. 


3.
Using explosives allows fishermen to obtain 
larger catch sizes compared to using nets 
or hooks. 
Dynamite fishing catches fish in a flash, but it's dangerous to fishermen, devastating to fishes and coral 
reefs, and even though prohibited in most countries, still used on coral reefs in Asia, Africa, the South 
Pacific, and the Caribbean.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Aquaculture
Section VII

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
The imbalance between a stagnant wild-caught 
ocean fisheries and the ever increasing demand 
for fish has opened the gateway for the 
aquaculture industry.


2.
The aquaculture sector is growing faster than any 
other major food production sector including both 
ocean and land.


3.
Today, farmed fish make up about 
49%
 of the 
fish that are eaten.


4.
A 2014 World Bank report predicts that 
62%
 of 
the world's seafood will be farm-raised by 2030
https://civileats.com/2018/08/16/can-aquaculture-survive-without-forage-fish/
Growing Scale of Aquaculture

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The report lists 10 areas of serious global aquaculture concerns.
1.
Coastal eutrophication and harmful algal blooms 
2.
Fish Feed Supply — reliance on wild caught forage fish 
3.
Habitat Destruction and Biodiversity Loss 
4.
Disease 
5.
Antibiotic Use 
6.
Green House Gas Emissions


7.
Transparency and Food Fraud


8.
Forced Labor


9.
Community Resistance


10.
Fish Welfare
2019 Report from Farm Animal Investment Risk and 
Return (FAIRR):  An ethical investment network
https://www.undercurrentnews.com/2019/06/06/report-climate-crisis-antibiotic-use-could-sink-aquaculture-industry/
https://www.fairr.org/article/shallow-returns-esg-issues-in-aquaculture/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Excretion and defecation 
by fish contained in 
shoreline pens has the 
potential to add nitrogen 
and phosphorus to the 
ocean and stimulate the 
growth of phytoplankton 
that eventually leads to 
anoxic (no oxygen) 
bottom waters or the 
development of harmful 
algal blooms
Eutrophication...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
An older 2014 Study 
showed that modern operating conditions have minimized 
impacts of most fish farms on marine water quality through better management. 


But More Recently, 
the FAIRR report notes the alarming frequency of recent major 
algal blooms such as the one that decimated 
Norwegian
 farmed salmon populations in 
May, 2019, with a loss of 10,000 tons of salmon. And one in 
Chile
 in 2016 that killed 
nearly 27 million salmon. 


The FAIRR report supports greater cultivation of species 
that remove marine pollution 
rather than contribute to it
 - 
such as mussels and oysters
. It was noted that farming 
these species brings minimal animal welfare concerns and does not require fishmeal-
based feed.”
https://www.undercurrentnews.com/2019/06/06/report-climate-crisis-antibiotic-use-could-sink-aquaculture-industry/
Coastal Eutrophication

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
Fed Aquaculture
 includes finfish such as salmon. These fish produce 
waste byproducts and require feed, which often — though not always — 
contains wild-caught fish. 


2.
Unfed Aquaculture
 includes 
seaweed
 and 
shellfish
 such as mussels 
and oysters. Seaweed requires only sunlight, and mussels and oysters 
feed off plankton that naturally occurs in seawater, sustaining themselves 
without additional inputs.
Aquaculture Can be Divided into Two Major Sectors: Fed and Unfed

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41893-018-0077-1
Fish Feed Supply
Small Forage Fish
 (e.g., sardine, 
anchovy and menhaden) account 
for 
40%
 of the total wild seafood 
caught globally. 


Aquaculture is now the primary 
user of forage fish 
— 
roughly 75%

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/16/opinion/16greenberg.html?_r=2&ref=global-home&
Human consumption of fish oil also 
big source of heavy fishing pressure 
of prey fish. 
Fish Oil Industry

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Forage  Fish are a Keystone 
Species in Marine Ecosystems
Forage fish are a key to the survival of apex 
predators like Tuna and Sharks, but also 
many sea birds and large marine mammals

© 2023 Bruce Monger
With “business as usual” the wild caught forage fish limit will be 
reached by 2037 (i.e., in just a few years)... 
The switch to alternative (possibly cheaper) feeds such as algae oil and 
insects, and greater inclusion of fish by-products may circumvent forage 
fish limits by mid-century. 


• However, if global diets shift to more seafood-heavy diets, then 
limits on wild caught forage fish could still be exceeded. 
https://civileats.com/2018/08/16/can-aquaculture-survive-without-forage-fish/
Fish Feed Supply

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Large-scale antibiotic use in farmed animals is 
contributing to a reservoir of antibiotic 
resistant bacteria.
  The majority of aquaculture production takes place in countries with 
“permissive regulations” and limited environmental monitoring.  


Much of the debate about antibiotic resistance focuses on two specific issues; 


1. The practice of delivering antibiotics 
prophylactically
 in small sub therapeutic doses 
in feed as a means to enhance the growth or prevent disease in fish and animals. 


2. The specific need to 
curb the use of critically important antibiotic used in the 
treatment of human health.
https://thefishsite.com/articles/antibiotics-in-aquaculture-are-they-needed
Disease and Antibiotic Use

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Mangrove Forests
 — In many tropical nations, coastal mangrove forests provide 
habitat for a diverse array of marine organisms, protect the coast against storms and 
improve water quality by acting as a filter. 


However, many mangrove forests have been cut down and replaced with ponds for 
shrimp farming
. 


After just a few years of intensive farming
, the accumulation of waste products and 
chemical pollution force farmers to abandon their ponds, clear a new section of mangrove 
forest and rebuild/destroy anew.
Habitat Destruction and Biodiversity Loss
https://www.seafoodwatch.org/ocean-issues/aquaculture/habitat-damage
Where and how fish are farmed can make a big the difference.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/06/global-aquaculture-poses-serious-risks-to-the-environment/
"With the world’s population expected to expand by 2.2 billion 
by 2050, it’s imperative that the industry adopts a more 
sustainable production model. 
Business as usual in the 
aquaculture sector is not an option.”
Maria Lettini, Director of FAIRR

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2021/08/05/Troubled-waters-How-high-fish-mortality-and-poor-
animal-welfare-threaten-the-profitability-of-aquaculture?
fbclid=IwAR3bJFKdmFRYPIdT4zW0IZBp1EmHfo3k8EwHdHEgyPw_H8Z-hhyZgE7UFHg
Optional Reading..

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Climate Change
Section VIII

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.fao.org/3/i9705en/i9705en.pdf
The UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) 
synthesis report states that models predict a 
7-12% 
decrease
 in maximum catch 
by 2050
 for business as 
usual emissions.


Impacts are much greater at regional scale. 
The biggest 
decreases are expected in the tropics.
  Catch potential 
at high latitudes are projected to increase, or show less of 
a decrease.


It is concluded that the 
interaction between ecosystem 
changes and management responses
 is crucial to 
minimize the threats and maximize the opportunities 
emerging from climate change.
* https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-the-high-emissions-rcp8-5-global-warming-scenario/
Climate Change Impacts

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/10/15/alaska-snow-crab-season-climate-change/
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-10-17/alaska-s-snow-crab-collapse-is-likely-tied-to-climate-change
The Alaska snow crab fishery was 
closed last year for the first time ever. 


The Bering Sea water temperatures were 
much warmer in 2018 and 2019 with low 
sea-ice cover. 


Snow crabs are
 
cold water animals and 
sensitive to the loss of sea ice.
 
Climate Change Impacts

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Hopeful Signs
Section IX

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Most of the big problems with 
overfishing is that is has become 
industrialized and taken over by large 
corporate holding companies who 
have little concern for conservation...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
By fighting for stricter conservation laws
 the hope is that industrial fishing will be 
diminished and that families and communities that have grown up with fishing on a 
human scale can continue to fish sustainably long into the future. 
A sustainable fishery means sustainable livelihoods 
for fishing families and communities

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Some regions are better managed than other regions

© 2023 Bruce Monger
•
Utilizes the Vessel 
Monitoring System 
(VMS)  


•
Designed to detect 
Illegal and Under 
Reported (IUU) 
Fishing Activities
Global Fish Watch:

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Designated protected area to allow marine 
organisms to grow to high abundance and 
persistently “seed” the adjacent areas that 
are open to fishing.


Note: How big each MPA should be and 
how closely spaced they should be is still 
very much an area of current research...   
Marine Protected 
Areas (MPAs)
 !!
© 2023 Bruce Monger

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
President Obama
 
signed a proclamation on 
September 25, 2014,
 
designating the largest 
marine reserve in the world. 


2.
To protect the whales, seabirds, sea turtles, 
fishes and corals in this region of the central 
and western Pacific Ocean, commercial 
fishing and mineral extraction will now be 
prohibited in this national monument.


3.
The expanded monument is now the largest 
protected area on the
 
planet (land or sea). It 
encompasses the seven islands and reefs of 
Wake, Johnston, Baker, Howland, Kingman, 
Jarvis and Palmyra, as well as the ocean 
around them.
http://www.marine-conservation.org
Largest US MPA Created In 2014

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.marine-conservation.org/what-we-do/program-areas/mpas/mpatlas/mpatlas-gallery/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sustainable Aquaculture

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://columbianewsservice.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/environmentally-responsible-aquaculture.jpg

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sustainable 
Shellfish
 
Aquaculture
http://www.eco-business.com/opinion/sustainable-shellfish-aquaculture/
The oyster may be key to 
sustainable aquaculture and 
clean coastlines

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Aquaculture of 
Planktivorous Fish (e.g. 
Tilapia) is Sustainable...
1. Planktivorous fish feed on 
zooplankton and are not fed 
wild caught prey fish


2. Consequently, these types 
of planktivorous fish can be 
raised sustainably

© 2023 Bruce Monger
US Farm-Raised Shrimp
1.
IF
 
done properly
 they can be a 
good environmental/sustainable 
choice 


US framed-raised shrimp are 
your best bet


2.
IF
 
done improperly
 in un-
regulated countries there are 
strong environmental risks (e.g, 
mangrove destruction and water 
pollution)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Guides to Eco-Friendly/Health-
Friendly Seafood Choices
https://www.seafoodwatch.org/seafood-recommendations/our-app

© 2023 Bruce Monger
There is also a handy 
smart-phone App version of this guide so you never 
have to be without your a guide when you go the store or restaurant!
Being Informed is Super Easy...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Marine Stewardship Council (MSC)
1.
The group certifies that fish are sustainable caught and the fish are then given the MSC label that consumers 
can use to make environmentally sound choices.


The MSC tries to harness consumer purchasing power to generate change and promote environmentally   
responsible stewardship of the world’s fisheries


2.
Formed in 1997 through cooperation between World Wildlife Fund (conservation group) and Unilever (large food 
processing corporation)


3.
Unilever agreed because it saw that preserving the fisheries was in its own self-interest 
4.
By November 2006, 21 fisheries had received the MSC label of which eight were found in the UK, six in the US, 
two in Australia, and the others in New Zealand, South Africa, the Netherlands, Mexico and Sweden. Twenty 
others were undergoing an assessment process to deter- mine their eligibility for certification
http://www.msc.org
/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Cornell Dining Serves 
MSC Seafood! 
https://news.cornell.edu/stories/2012/08/cornell-first-ivy-be-certified-sustainable-seafood
